Uptime Kuma: the best self-hosted monitoring dashboard.

‚Ä¢ Monitor HTTP, TCP, DNS, Docker containers
‚Ä¢ Push notifications (Telegram, Discord, Slack, email)
‚Ä¢ Status pages for your services
‚Ä¢ One Docker container, 50MB RAM

No excuse not to run this. #selfhosted

Paperless-ngx turns your filing cabinet into a searchable database. Scan documents, OCR extracts text, AI suggests tags.

Docker Compose + a $50 document scanner = paperless office in an afternoon. #selfhosted #paperless

n8n is the self-hosted Zapier. Visual workflow automation with 400+ integrations.

Connect your self-hosted services: new Nextcloud file ‚Üí process with Stirling-PDF ‚Üí save to Paperless-ngx ‚Üí notify via ntfy.

One Docker container. #selfhosted #automation
Docker tip: use `docker system prune -a --volumes` to reclaim disk space. One command wipes unused images, stopped containers, and orphan volumes. Run it monthly. #selfhosted #docker
Always pin your Docker image tags. `image: postgres:16` is stable. `image: postgres:latest` will surprise you at the worst possible time. #selfhosted #homelab
Self-hosting tip: set `restart: unless-stopped` on every Docker Compose service. Your stack comes back automatically after a reboot. No cron jobs needed. #selfhosted
Run `docker compose logs -f --tail=50` to follow live logs across your entire stack. Add a service name at the end to filter to just one container. #docker #homelab
Self-hosting security 101: put Caddy in front of everything. It auto-provisions HTTPS certificates and reverse proxies with zero config files. #selfhosted #homelab
Want to monitor your Docker containers? Portainer CE is free, runs in one container, and gives you a web UI for managing your entire stack. #selfhosted #docker
Use Docker networks to isolate services. Apps that don't need to talk to each other shouldn't share a network. Security through segmentation. #selfhosted #docker
Back up your Docker volumes, not your containers. Containers are disposable ‚Äî your data isn't. `docker run --rm -v vol:/data -v $(pwd):/backup alpine tar czf /backup/vol.tar.gz /data` #homelab
Healthchecks in Docker Compose are underrated. Add a healthcheck to your database so dependent services wait until it's actually ready, not just started. #docker #selfhosted
Use `.env` files in Docker Compose for passwords and config. Never hardcode secrets in your YAML. Keep `.env` out of version control with `.gitignore`. #selfhosted #homelab
Google Photos: $30/yr for 100GB. Immich on a mini PC: $0/yr after a ~$200 one-time investment. Same AI search, same mobile app, infinite storage. #selfhosted
1Password family plan: $60/yr. Vaultwarden on Docker: $0/yr. Same browser extensions, same mobile apps. All your passwords stay on your hardware. #selfhosted
Notion + Dropbox + Google Calendar + Todoist = ~$35/mo. Nextcloud does all four for $0/mo on a $150 mini PC. The math isn't even close. #selfhosted #homelab
Unpopular opinion: Docker Compose is better than Kubernetes for 90% of self-hosters. If your stack fits on one machine, k8s is just overhead. #selfhosted #homelab
Hot take: Pi-hole alone justifies buying a Raspberry Pi. Network-wide ad blocking for every device in your house ‚Äî including smart TVs and phones. #selfhosted
Controversial: the best backup strategy is the one you actually test. Having 3 copies across 2 media with 1 offsite means nothing if you've never restored from it. #homelab
The hardest part of self-hosting isn't the setup. It's remembering to update your containers. Set up Watchtower or Diun and stop worrying about it. #selfhosted
What was the first thing you self-hosted? For most people it's Pi-hole or Nextcloud. Drop yours below. #selfhosted #homelab
Self-hosters: what's your total monthly power cost for running your homelab? Curious how it compares to the cloud subscriptions it replaced. #homelab
You can only self-host 3 things for the rest of your life. What do you pick? Mine: Vaultwarden, Immich, Jellyfin. #selfhosted #homelab

Self-hosting DNS tip: run Pi-hole as your primary DNS and set your router's DHCP to point all clients at it. Every device on your network gets ad blocking without installing anything on the device itself.

Works for smart TVs, phones, IoT devices, guests.

#selfhosted #pihole #dns #privacy #homelab #foss #opensource

Docker Compose depends_on only waits for the container to start, NOT for the service inside to be ready. Use healthchecks:

```yaml
healthcheck:
  test: ["CMD", "pg_isready", "-U", "postgres"]
  interval: 5s
  retries: 5
```

Then `depends_on: db: condition: service_healthy`

#selfhosted #docker #homelab #foss #linux

Watchtower monitors your running Docker containers and automatically pulls updated images, then recreates the container with the same config.

One container watching all your other containers. Set a schedule so updates don't surprise you mid-day.

#selfhosted #docker #homelab #foss #opensource #linux

Tired of managing SSL certificates manually? Caddy handles it automatically with Let's Encrypt. Your entire reverse proxy config can be as simple as:

```
app.example.com {
  reverse_proxy localhost:8080
}
```

HTTPS just works. No certbot cron jobs.

#selfhosted #caddy #letsencrypt #homelab #foss #linux #opensource

Label everything in Docker Compose. Add labels for Traefik routing, Watchtower enable/disable, backup inclusion, and your own documentation. Future you will thank present you.

```yaml
labels:
  - "com.centurylinklabs.watchtower.enable=true"
  - "backup.include=true"
```

#selfhosted #docker #homelab #foss #linux #opensource

Use `docker stats` to see real-time CPU, memory, and network usage of every running container. It's the quickest way to find which service is hogging resources.

Pair it with ctop for a nicer terminal UI.

#selfhosted #docker #monitoring #homelab #linux #foss #opensource

Cloud subscription audit:

Google One 200GB: $3/mo
iCloud 200GB: $3/mo  
Dropbox Plus: $12/mo
1Password Family: $5/mo
Spotify (for podcasts you could self-host): $11/mo

Total: $34/mo = $408/yr

A mini PC + external drive: ~$250 one-time. Run Nextcloud + Vaultwarden + Audiobookshelf. Done.

#selfhosted #homelab #privacy #foss #opensource

Plex Pass lifetime: $120. Annual: $40/yr.
Jellyfin: $0. Forever. No account required, no telemetry, no ads for your own media.

Same hardware transcoding support. Same client apps (mostly). Your media library, your rules.

#selfhosted #jellyfin #plex #mediaserver #foss #opensource #homelab

Running a self-hosted stack on a mini PC costs roughly $3-5/month in electricity (15-25W idle). That's less than a single cloud subscription.

My stack: Nextcloud, Immich, Vaultwarden, Jellyfin, Pi-hole, Home Assistant, Uptime Kuma. All on one N100 box.

#selfhosted #homelab #minipc #foss #opensource #linux

Opinion: Nginx Proxy Manager made reverse proxying accessible, but Caddy is the better long-term choice. Automatic HTTPS with zero configuration, a clean config syntax, and no PHP/MySQL dependencies.

If you're starting fresh, skip NPM and go straight to Caddy.

#selfhosted #caddy #nginx #reverseproxy #homelab #foss #opensource

The self-hosting community sometimes overthinks hardware. An Intel N100 mini PC handles Nextcloud, Jellyfin, Pi-hole, Vaultwarden, and a dozen other services simultaneously. You don't need a rack server to start.

Start small. Scale when you actually need to.

#selfhosted #homelab #hardware #minipc #foss #opensource

Self-hosting is not about saving money. It's about ownership.

Google can shut down a product tomorrow (and has, dozens of times). Your self-hosted instance only goes away when YOU decide.

The money savings are real, but control is the actual value.

#selfhosted #privacy #digitalownership #foss #opensource #homelab

Unpopular take: you should run automatic updates on most self-hosted apps. Yes, something might break. But running months-old containers with known CVEs is worse.

Use Watchtower with a schedule. Pin critical databases. Auto-update everything else.

#selfhosted #security #docker #homelab #foss #opensource #linux

Question for the Fediverse self-hosters:

What's the one app you tried to self-host, gave up on, and went back to the cloud version?

For me it was email. Running your own mail server is technically possible but deliverability is a full-time job.

#selfhosted #homelab #foss #opensource #linux #docker

What does your self-hosted monitoring stack look like?

I've seen everything from a simple Uptime Kuma instance to full Prometheus + Grafana + Loki setups.

Curious what the community considers the sweet spot between too simple and overengineered.

#selfhosted #monitoring #homelab #foss #opensource #linux

If you could recommend exactly ONE self-hosted app to someone who's never self-hosted anything, what would it be and why?

Rules: it has to be easy to set up, immediately useful, and work reliably.

#selfhosted #homelab #beginners #foss #opensource #docker #linux

Want to try a self-hosted app without committing? Run it in a separate Docker Compose project with its own network and volumes. If you don't like it, `docker compose down -v` and it's gone. Zero cleanup.
Set `PUID` and `PGID` environment variables in LinuxServer.io containers to match your host user. This avoids permission issues where the container creates files your host user can't read.

If your self-hosted service is slow, check if Docker is writing logs to disk unbounded. A busy container can generate gigabytes of logs. Set max-size and max-file in your daemon.json or per-container logging config.
Tailscale is the easiest way to access your self-hosted services remotely. Install it on your server and your phone. No port forwarding, no dynamic DNS, no VPN server to manage. It just works.

I added up what I was paying for cloud services before self-hosting: Google One, iCloud, 1Password, a VPN, and Plex Pass. $52/month. My entire self-hosted stack runs on a $180 mini PC drawing 15 watts. Paid for itself in under 4 months.

Google Workspace for a family of 4: $28/month for email, calendar, docs, and 100GB each. Nextcloud on a mini PC: free after hardware cost, unlimited storage, same features. The only thing Google does better is search inside docs.

People think self-hosting is expensive. Here's a starter kit: used Dell Optiplex ($80), 1TB external drive ($50), Ubuntu Server (free). Total: $130. That box runs Pi-hole, Nextcloud, Vaultwarden, and Jellyfin simultaneously without breaking a sweat.

I think the reason more people don't self-host is that every guide assumes you already know Docker, networking, and Linux. The actual setup for most apps is 10 lines of YAML. The barrier is documentation, not complexity.

Hot take: Immich is the most important self-hosted app right now. Not because photo management is hard, but because Google Photos is training AI on your family's photos and you can't opt out. Immich gives you the same features with actual privacy.

Reverse proxies are the single most confusing topic in self-hosting, and it doesn't have to be that way. Caddy reduced it to 3 lines of config. The community should stop recommending nginx to beginners.

Controversial: most people don't need Kubernetes, Proxmox, or a rack server. A single mini PC running Docker Compose handles everything a household needs. The homelab community optimizes for fun, which is great, but beginners shouldn't feel like they need a server rack.
Genuine question: what self-hosted app has the best mobile experience? I find that's where most projects fall short. The web UIs are great but the phone apps range from decent to nonexistent.
What's your self-hosted backup strategy? I see everything from "I don't" to elaborate 3-2-1 setups with offsite replication. Curious where most people actually land in practice.
How many Docker containers are you running right now? I just counted mine and I'm at 23 across 8 compose files. Wondering if that's normal or if I have a problem.

Hot take: you don't need Kubernetes for self-hosting. Docker Compose handles 95% of homelab workloads. Save K8s for when you have 3+ nodes and need actual orchestration. A single docker-compose.yml with 30 services is perfectly fine.

#selfhosted #homelab #docker #kubernetes

Self-hosting tip: always set `restart: unless-stopped` on your Docker containers, not `restart: always`. The difference? `unless-stopped` respects when you manually stop a container. `always` restarts it even after you deliberately stopped it.

#selfhosted #docker #homelab #linux

The real cost of self-hosting isn't hardware ‚Äî it's your time. A $200 mini PC runs for years. But spending a weekend debugging DNS resolution because you didn't read the Nextcloud docs? That's the real expense. Always read the official docs first.

#selfhosted #homelab #nextcloud #dns

What's your most underrated self-hosted app? Mine: ntfy. Push notifications from any script with a single curl command. Cron job failed? Docker container unhealthy? Send a notification to your phone in one line of bash.

#selfhosted #homelab #docker #foss

PSA for anyone running Immich: the face recognition model has gotten significantly better in recent releases. If you trained it early on and it's making bad groupings, delete the facial recognition data and let it re-scan. Night and day difference.

#selfhosted #immich #photography #homelab

Unpopular opinion: Nginx Proxy Manager is fine. Yes, Traefik and Caddy are more powerful. But NPM's web UI means you'll actually configure it instead of procrastinating on learning YAML/Caddyfile syntax. The best tool is the one you use.

#selfhosted #homelab #docker #reverseproxy

If you're running Pi-hole, check if your upstream DNS is Cloudflare (1.1.1.1) or Google (8.8.8.8). Both log queries. Switch to Unbound for recursive DNS ‚Äî it queries root servers directly. No third-party sees your full query history.

#selfhosted #pihole #dns #privacy #homelab

Proxmox storage tip: don't use raw qcow2 files on ZFS. Use ZFS zvols instead. ZFS can't deduplicate or snapshot inside a file ‚Äî it needs block-level access. Use `virtio-scsi` with raw zvols for best VM performance.

#selfhosted #proxmox #zfs #homelab #virtualization

The first 3 things to self-host (in order):

1. Vaultwarden ‚Äî password manager. Security foundation.
2. Pi-hole ‚Äî network-wide ad blocking. Instant quality of life.
3. Reverse proxy (Caddy/NPM) ‚Äî makes everything else easier.

Disagree? What's your top 3?

#selfhosted #homelab #docker #foss

Docker networking cheat sheet:

‚Ä¢ bridge (default): containers share a network, get internal IPs
‚Ä¢ host: container uses host's network stack directly
‚Ä¢ macvlan: container gets its own IP on your LAN

Use macvlan when the app needs to appear as a separate device (Home Assistant, Pi-hole).

#selfhosted #docker #homelab #networking

Docker Compose handles 95% of homelab workloads. A single docker-compose.yml with 30 services is fine.

Save K8s for when you have 3+ nodes and need actual orchestration.

The difference? unless-stopped respects when you manually stop a container. always restarts it even after you deliberately stopped it.

Always read the official docs first.

Push notifications from any script with a single curl command:

curl -d "Backup completed" ntfy.sh/mytopic

Cron job failed? Docker container unhealthy? One line of bash ‚Üí phone notification.

Night and day difference.

Proxmox + ZFS tip: don't use qcow2 disk images on ZFS. Use zvols instead. ZFS needs block-level access for snapshots and dedup to work properly. Raw zvols with virtio-scsi give you the best VM performance.
Docker tip: use `docker system prune -a --volumes` quarterly to reclaim disk space. Just ran it on my homelab and freed 47GB of dangling images and unused volumes. #selfhosted
Hot take: Cloudflare Tunnels are the best thing to happen to self-hosting in years. No port forwarding, no DDNS, free tier is generous. Zero-trust access to your services in 5 minutes.
What's the most underrated self-hosted app you run? Mine is Paperless-ngx. Went from 3 filing cabinets to zero. OCR search across every document I've ever received.
Stop using :latest tags in Docker Compose. Pin to a specific version (e.g., immich:v1.99.0). When something breaks at 2am you'll want to know exactly what changed. #homelab
You don't need a rack server to start self-hosting. A Raspberry Pi 4 handles Pi-hole, Vaultwarden, and a reverse proxy without breaking a sweat. Start small. Grow when you need to.

Compose trick: use `depends_on` with health checks instead of bare `depends_on`. Your app won't start until the database is actually ready, not just running.

depends_on:
  db:
    condition: service_healthy
Replaced Google Photos, Spotify, Google Drive, and a VPN subscription. Total cloud cost before: $43/month. Self-hosted cost: $8/month in electricity. The mini PC paid for itself in 5 months.
Your family photos shouldn't live on someone else's server. Google killed Picasa. They'll deprecate Photos features whenever they want. Self-host Immich and own your memories permanently.

Docker networking tip that took me too long to learn: create named networks in Compose instead of relying on the default bridge.

Named networks let containers across different Compose files communicate. Default bridges are isolated per project.

```yaml
networks:
  proxy:
    external: true
```

Then join it from any stack. #selfhosted #docker #homelab #linux

I think Vaultwarden is the single highest-impact self-hosted service you can run.

Not the flashiest. Not the most fun to set up. But moving your passwords off a cloud provider's servers is the biggest privacy win per hour of effort.

If you self-host exactly one thing, make it this. #selfhosted #foss #privacy #security #homelab

Question for the #selfhosted community: what's your backup strategy?

I see too many homelabs with zero off-site backup. RAID is not backup. Snapshots are not backup.

My setup: nightly Restic to Backblaze B2, costs $5/month for 800GB. What's yours? #homelab #linux #docker #foss

PSA: If you're running Nextcloud in Docker, set these PHP memory limits in your environment or you'll get random 500 errors on large file uploads:

PHP_MEMORY_LIMIT=1G
PHP_UPLOAD_LIMIT=10G

The defaults are absurdly low for any real usage. #selfhosted #nextcloud #docker #linux #foss

Controversial opinion in the #foss world: I actually recommend Tailscale over WireGuard for most people.

Yes, WireGuard is fully open source and Tailscale has proprietary coordination servers. But Tailscale's UX means people actually USE it instead of leaving ports exposed.

Security you use beats security you don't. #selfhosted #homelab #linux #privacy

Healthcheck pattern for Postgres in Docker Compose that actually works:

```yaml
healthcheck:
  test: ["CMD-SHELL", "pg_isready -U $$POSTGRES_USER -d $$POSTGRES_DB"]
  interval: 10s
  timeout: 5s
  retries: 5
```

Use double $$ for environment variables inside healthcheck commands ‚Äî Docker Compose interprets single $ as variable substitution. #docker #selfhosted #homelab #linux

The self-hosting community in 2026 is incredible. Five years ago, deploying Nextcloud meant wrestling with Apache configs for hours. Now it's a 15-line Docker Compose file.

What app has had the biggest improvement in ease of deployment? My vote: Immich. Went from nightmare to single-command. #selfhosted #foss #homelab #docker #opensource

Quick self-hosting cost breakdown that surprises people:

‚òÅÔ∏è Cloud: Google One ($30) + Spotify ($11) + 1Password ($36/yr) + VPN ($5) = ~$49/month

üè† Self-hosted: Mini PC ($200 one-time) + electricity ($8/month) = $8/month ongoing

Break-even in under 5 months. Everything after that is savings.

#selfhosted #homelab #foss #linux #privacy

Docker volume tip: never use bind mounts with relative paths in production Compose files. Always use absolute paths or named volumes. Relative paths break when you run compose from a different directory, and debugging that at midnight is not fun.

The best home server OS in 2026 is just Debian 12 with Docker. Not Proxmox, not TrueNAS, not Unraid. Plain Debian.

If you're running everything in containers anyway, the hypervisor layer just adds complexity. Save Proxmox for when you actually need VMs.

Honest question: has anyone actually saved money with Unraid? The license costs $60-130, plus you're locked into their ecosystem. Meanwhile Debian + mergerfs + SnapRAID does the same thing for free. What am I missing?

If you're exposing self-hosted services to the internet, please use Authelia or Authentik as an SSO layer. A reverse proxy alone is not enough. One misconfigured app and your entire network is exposed.

Authelia is lighter. Authentik is more feature-rich. Pick one and deploy it today.

Every time someone says self-hosting is too hard for normal people, I think about how millions of people manage WordPress sites. Self-hosting has already gone mainstream ‚Äî people just don't call it that.

The tooling caught up. Portainer, CasaOS, Cosmos ‚Äî the UX gap is closing fast.

Compose trick that saves hours of debugging: always set explicit container names.

container_name: immich-server

Without it, Docker generates names like "immich-immich-server-1" and your logs, networking, and scripts all reference different names depending on the directory you launched from.

What killed your last self-hosting setup? For me it was not having automated backups. Lost a Nextcloud instance with 2 years of files because the SSD died and I kept saying "I'll set up backups this weekend."

Now Restic runs nightly to B2 before anything else gets deployed.

The number one mistake new self-hosters make: trying to replace everything at once. Pick one service. Get it running reliably. Understand the maintenance burden. Then add the next one.

I've seen too many people spin up 20 containers in a weekend and abandon everything a month later.

text: Docker tip: Use `restart: unless-stopped` on every service. Your homelab shouldn't need babysitting after a reboot. #selfhosted
Stop using `docker run` for everything. Docker Compose is free, readable, and version-controllable. Use it. #docker
Docker volumes > bind mounts for databases. Named volumes are managed by Docker, survive container recreation, and are easier to back up.
Use `docker system prune -a --volumes` to reclaim disk space. Old images add up fast when you're running 30+ services.
Set memory limits on your containers. One misbehaving service shouldn't take down your entire homelab. #homelab
Pin your Docker image tags. `latest` today might break your setup tomorrow. Use specific versions. #selfhosted
Docker networks: create custom bridge networks for each stack. Don't dump everything on the default bridge. #docker
`docker compose logs -f --tail=50` ‚Äî your first debugging step for any container issue. Always. #selfhosted
Use `.env` files with Docker Compose. Hardcoded passwords in YAML files end up in git repos. Ask me how I know.
Docker healthchecks are underused. Add them to every service. Your monitoring stack will thank you. #docker
Caddy vs Nginx for self-hosting: Caddy auto-renews TLS certs with zero config. That alone makes it the default choice. #selfhosted
Traefik is powerful but over-engineered for most homelabs. Caddy does 90% of what you need in 10% of the config lines.
Self-hosting rule: never expose services without a reverse proxy. Caddy + wildcard DNS takes 10 minutes to set up.
Nginx Proxy Manager has a nice UI, but it adds a database dependency for something that should be a config file. Just learn Caddy.
Immich vs Google Photos: Immich handles facial recognition, ML-powered search, and mobile backup. 50MB RAM. Google wants your data + $30/year.
Immich is still pre-1.0 but already better than PhotoPrism for most use cases. ML features, mobile app, active development. #selfhosted
Running Immich? Enable GPU transcoding. Video processing drops from hours to minutes with even a basic iGPU. #homelab
PhotoPrism tip: Set PHOTOPRISM_WORKERS to match your CPU cores. Default of 0 auto-detects but sometimes underestimates.
Jellyfin vs Plex: Jellyfin is fully open-source, no account required, no phoning home. It just works. That's the whole argument.
Navidrome for music, Jellyfin for video. Don't make one app do both. Navidrome is lighter, faster, and has better Subsonic API support.
Jellyfin hardware transcoding on Intel N100: enable VA-API, pass through /dev/dri. 4K transcoding at 15W total system power.
Plex still requires an account and phones home. If that doesn't bother you, fine. But Jellyfin doesn't. #foss
Vaultwarden: 50MB RAM. Official Bitwarden: 2GB+ (MSSQL + .NET). For personal/family use, this isn't even close. #selfhosted
Running Vaultwarden? Enable WEBSOCKET_ENABLED=true and set up the /notifications/hub path in your reverse proxy. Real-time sync.
Self-hosting your password manager is the single highest-ROI self-hosting project. 10 minutes to deploy Vaultwarden. Years of value.
Home Assistant tip: run it on dedicated hardware, not in a Docker stack with 20 other things. Zigbee/Z-Wave timing matters.
Home Assistant is the one self-hosted app where 'just use the cloud version' is wrong. Your smart home shouldn't depend on someone else's servers.
HACS (Home Assistant Community Store) is essential. Official integrations are great, but HACS fills the gaps. #homeassistant
Syncthing vs Nextcloud for file sync: Syncthing is peer-to-peer, zero server maintenance. Nextcloud is a full platform. Pick what you actually need.
Nextcloud runs fine on modest hardware. 2 cores, 2GB RAM, PostgreSQL instead of MySQL. Don't let the 'requirements' scare you.
Syncthing conflict handling is elegant ‚Äî it keeps both versions. No silent overwrites. No data loss. #selfhosted
WireGuard connects in under a second. OpenVPN takes 10-30 seconds. For mobile use, WireGuard isn't just faster ‚Äî it's a different experience.
Tailscale is great but it's a company. Headscale gives you the same mesh VPN with zero external dependencies. Self-host your control plane.
WireGuard tip: use AllowedIPs = 0.0.0.0/0 for full tunnel, or specific subnets for split tunnel. Most people want split tunnel.
Every self-hoster needs a VPN solution. WireGuard for raw connections, Tailscale/Headscale for mesh. No excuses for exposing services raw.
Pi-hole vs AdGuard Home: AGH has a cleaner UI and built-in DoH/DoT. Pi-hole has a bigger community. Both work. I'd start with AGH today.
Run two DNS instances on separate hardware. When your single Pi-hole goes down for updates, your entire network shouldn't lose DNS.

Docker logging can eat your disk alive. Set global log limits in /etc/docker/daemon.json:

```json
{"log-driver": "json-file", "log-opts": {"max-size": "10m", "max-file": "3"}}
```

Your future self will thank you.

Docker health checks are criminally underused. Add them to every service:

```yaml
healthcheck:

  interval: 30s
  timeout: 10s
  retries: 3
```

Your monitoring and orchestration tools depend on these.

SSH hardening checklist:

1. Disable password auth (PasswordAuthentication no)
2. Use key-only login
3. Change default port (Security through obscurity helps with bots)
4. Install fail2ban or CrowdSec
5. Disable root login

5 minutes, 95% of attacks neutralized.

CrowdSec vs fail2ban:

fail2ban: reactive, local-only, regex-based
CrowdSec: proactive, community intelligence, bouncer architecture

CrowdSec blocks IPs other people already identified as malicious. That's a fundamental advantage.

Every self-hosted service accessible from the internet needs:

1. Reverse proxy (TLS termination)
2. Authentication proxy (Authelia/Authentik)
3. Rate limiting

'Self-hosting is lonely.' The r/selfhosted and r/homelab communities have 500K+ members. Mastodon #selfhosted is incredibly active.
Running 10 services well is better than running 50 services poorly. Focus on reliability, then expand.
Google Workspace Business: $7/user/month. Nextcloud + OnlyOffice + Radicale: $0/user. Self-hosted productivity suite.

YAML indentation errors cause more homelab downtime than actual failures. Use a YAML linter or `docker compose config` before deploying.
What's the self-hosted app you recommend most to beginners? I always say Vaultwarden. Biggest impact, smallest effort.
Use `docker compose pull` before `up -d` to check for updates without restarting services. Pull first, review, then restart.
Traggo: self-hosted time tracking. Simple, clean interface. Track how you spend time on projects without sending that data to a SaaS. #selfhosted
'Containers are insecure by default.' Linux namespaces + cgroups provide real isolation. Add read-only fs + non-root and you're ahead of bare metal.
The beauty of Docker Compose: your entire infrastructure is documented in one file. New server? Copy the file. Done.
Authelia vs Authentik: Authelia is a forward auth proxy. Authentik is a full identity provider. Most homelabs need Authelia. Enterprises need Authentik.
Hetzner dedicated: 64GB RAM, 8 cores, 2x NVMe for ‚Ç¨47/month. Run 100+ services. Try getting that performance from any cloud provider.
Docker compose watch is great for development. File changes auto-trigger rebuilds. No more manual restart cycles.
Umami: privacy-focused web analytics. No cookies, GDPR compliant, beautiful dashboard. Self-hosted alternative to Google Analytics.
Name one cloud service that's genuinely BETTER than its self-hosted alternative. I'll start: Spotify's recommendation algorithm.
NVMe SSDs in your home server are worth the premium over SATA. The speed difference is real, especially for databases and container images.
Use `docker system events` to watch real-time Docker events. Useful for debugging startup issues and monitoring container lifecycle.
Wallabag: self-hosted read-it-later. Save articles, read offline, no ads. Pocket replacement that respects your privacy. #selfhosted #foss
'Self-hosting is expensive.' My total cost: $150 hardware + $5/month electricity. Cloud equivalent: $80+/month. Do the math.
Labels in Docker Compose are the hidden feature. Use them for Traefik routing, Watchtower control, Prometheus discovery, and documentation.
Caddy vs Nginx: Caddy wins on simplicity and auto-TLS. Nginx wins on raw performance and ecosystem. For homelabs: Caddy. For production: either.

Use Docker buildx for multi-platform builds. `docker buildx build --platform linux/amd64,linux/arm64 .` covers most hardware.

Your homelab should be cattle, not pets. If a container dies, it should come back automatically. If a server dies, you should be able to rebuild from config.
Use `COMPOSE_FILE` env var to specify multiple compose files: `COMPOSE_FILE=base.yaml:monitoring.yaml`. Modular composition.
'You'll lose all your data if your server crashes.' That's what backups are for. Restic to B2 runs every night. I could rebuild in an hour.

Use `docker compose cp` to copy files in/out of running containers. No need to exec and pipe through tar anymore.

Immich's shared albums feature makes it a real Google Photos replacement. My family uploads to shared albums without knowing it's self-hosted.

Self-hosting pro tip: document everything in a private git repo. Docker compose files, config snippets, setup notes. Future you needs this.
Self-hosted monitoring showed me my ISP lies about my uptime. 99.9% advertised, 99.2% measured. The evidence is useful.
Kavita: self-hosted manga/comic/ebook reader. Clean interface, OPDS support, reading progress sync. Calibre-web alternative with better UX.

Docker Hub rate limits pushing people to self-host their own registries is peak irony. Use Harbor or distribution/distribution.

Linkwarden: self-hosted bookmark manager with link archiving. Saves snapshots of pages so you never lose content to link rot.

Docker resource limits: set them on every container. One memory leak shouldn't OOM-kill your entire server. It's a 3-line config.
Tubearchivist: download and organize YouTube videos locally. Full search, transcripts, sponsor segments marked. Your own YouTube archive.

Use `docker compose exec --user 1000:1000` to run commands as non-root inside containers. Don't create files as root unless you must.
Atuin: self-hosted shell history sync. Search your entire command history across all your machines. Never forget a command again.
Be honest: how many Docker containers are you running right now? I'm at 42. Each one earns its place.

Docker image layer caching: put your least-changing instructions first in Dockerfile. OS packages before app code. Faster rebuilds.
The self-hosting renaissance is real. Five years ago, half these apps didn't exist. Now there's a self-hosted alternative for almost everything.
Beszel is the server monitoring I always wanted. Lightweight agent, clean dashboard, Docker-aware. Doesn't need Prometheus + Grafana for simple setups.
People say self-hosted alternatives are worse than cloud. Have they tried Immich? Jellyfin? Vaultwarden? These aren't compromises ‚Äî they're genuine alternatives.

Docker env_file directive > inline environment variables. Cleaner YAML, reusable configs, secrets stay in one place. #docker
Your homelab doesn't need 10Gbe networking. Gigabit handles 30+ containers and 4K streaming simultaneously. Save your money for storage.
Healthchecks.io alternative: self-host Vigil or Gatus. Monitor your cron jobs and services from your own infrastructure.
Docker container ordering: `depends_on` with `condition: service_healthy` beats sleep hacks. Proper startup, every time. #docker
What's the most hours you've spent debugging a self-hosted service? Mine: 6 hours on Nextcloud LDAP. Never again.
Open-source software wins in the long run. Every proprietary tool you depend on is a risk. Gitea > GitHub, Immich > Google Photos.
Use docker compose alpha publish to export your stack as an OCI artifact. Versioned, shareable infrastructure bundles. #docker
Bitwarden Teams: $4/user/month. Vaultwarden: $0/user. Your family of 5 saves $240/year. That pays for server hardware. #selfhosted
Myth: you can't game on a home server. Reality: Steam Remote Play + Sunshine + Moonlight. Self-hosted cloud gaming from your own GPU.
Use `docker volume ls --filter dangling=true` to find orphaned volumes wasting disk space. Then prune them. #docker
Nginx is the Apache of reverse proxies. Still works, still everywhere, but newer options are better for new projects.
Grafana Alloy (formerly Agent): lightweight telemetry collector. Sends metrics from any source to any destination. #monitoring
Which self-hosted app has the best documentation? My vote: Home Assistant. Extensive, searchable, community-contributed.
Kopia vs Duplicati: Kopia is newer, faster, better UX. Duplicati is mature, battle-tested, but heavier. Kopia for new setups.
Tag your Docker images with dates: myapp:2026-02-20. If latest breaks, you know exactly which version worked. #docker
Self-hosting your own git repos isn't paranoia ‚Äî it's insurance. GitHub has had multi-hour outages. Your Forgejo hasn't.
Prometheus + Alertmanager: define alerts as code. 'If disk > 80%, notify Telegram.' Infrastructure as code for monitoring. #selfhosted
'Docker is just a fad.' Docker Hub has 100B+ pulls. Kubernetes runs half the internet. Containerization won. It's infrastructure now.
What's your server naming convention? Mine: function-based (media-01, proxy-01). Some people use mythology, planets, or random words.
GitHub Teams: $4/user/month. Forgejo: $0/user, self-hosted, CI included. For small teams, this is a no-brainer. #foss
Docker Compose --wait flag: `docker compose up --wait` blocks until all services are healthy. Great for scripts and CI. #docker
The self-hosting community on Reddit is genuinely one of the best tech communities. Helpful, patient, and welcoming to beginners.
Caddy's on-demand TLS: automatically provisions certificates for any domain that points to your server. Dynamic multi-tenant hosting. #caddy
Myth: ZFS needs tons of RAM. Reality: 4GB is fine for a homelab NAS with a few TB. The '1GB per TB' rule is for enterprise workloads.
Best free tier for offsite backups: Backblaze B2 (10GB), Cloudflare R2 (10GB), Oracle Cloud (10GB). Where do you store yours?
Docker volume permissions: match the container's UID/GID with your host user. Prevents permission denied errors on bind mounts. #docker
Self-hosting taught me more about security than any course. When it's YOUR server, you actually care about best practices.
Semaphore: self-hosted Ansible UI. Run playbooks from a web interface. Scheduled runs, inventory management, secrets vault. #ansible
Kavita vs Calibre-web: Kavita has native manga support and better UI. Calibre-web integrates with Calibre libraries. Both are solid.
Grammarly: $144/year. LanguageTool self-hosted: $0. Same grammar checking. Runs locally. Your text stays private.
Use `docker compose run --rm service command` for one-off tasks in the service's context. Database migrations, admin scripts, etc. #docker
Authentik is a full identity provider. SAML, OIDC, LDAP, RADIUS. Enterprise SSO on your homelab. Overkill? Maybe. Cool? Definitely.
Every Docker image over 500MB should explain itself. If your Go binary is in a 1GB image, you're doing multi-stage builds wrong.
What self-hosted service has the steepest learning curve? My nomination: mail server. Runners up: pfSense, Kubernetes.
'Only tech people can use self-hosted apps.' My parents use Vaultwarden and Jellyfin. They think it's 'the family app.'
Docker compose restart: `docker compose restart service` restarts without recreating. Faster when you just need a service bounce. #docker
ChangeDetection.io monitors any webpage for changes. Price drops, job postings, documentation updates. Surprisingly addictive to use.
ARM64 Docker image support has gotten much better. Most popular images are multi-arch now. The Pi compatibility excuse is dying.
Slack Pro: $7.25/user/month. Rocket.Chat self-hosted: $0/user. Same features, your data. Even Matrix/Element works great.
How many services is too many on one server? I say if your monitoring doesn't show resource pressure, you're fine. Add more.
Use Docker build --target debug for development images with extra tools. Production targets stay lean. Multi-stage FTW. #docker
Miniflux: the RSS reader for people who think other RSS readers do too much. Go binary, PostgreSQL, Fever API. That's it. #rss
The best investment in your homelab: a good UPS, a fast SSD, and automated backups. Everything else is optional.
Docker Compose watch: auto-rebuild on file changes. Define sync and rebuild actions per service. Dev workflow game changer. #docker
Vaultwarden supports Passkeys now. Passwordless login stored in your own vault. The future of auth, self-hosted. #selfhosted #security
Netdata vs Beszel for server monitoring: Netdata for deep real-time metrics. Beszel for clean overview of multiple servers. #monitoring
Hot take: if you're not testing your backups, you don't have backups. You have hopes. Schedule a restore test. #selfhosted
Self-hosting is choosing inconvenience now for independence later. The inconvenience shrinks over time. The independence only grows.
Docker Compose extend is the DRY principle for infrastructure. Common config in base.yaml, specific overrides per stack. #docker
Myth: cloud is always faster. My self-hosted Nextcloud on NVMe SSD has lower latency than Google Drive. LAN > WAN. Physics wins.
Headscale + Tailscale clients: mesh VPN without Tailscale's servers. Full control of your coordination server. Free and open source.
Docker tip: run database backups BEFORE container updates. `docker compose exec db pg_dump` saves you from upgrade disasters. 10 seconds of prevention.
Self-hosted AI is the next frontier. Ollama made it accessible. Open WebUI made it user-friendly. The gap with cloud AI shrinks every month.
Vaultwarden organizations: share password collections with family members. Each person has their own vault PLUS shared folders. Replaced 1Password Family.
If you could self-host one service that doesn't exist yet, what would it be? I want a self-hosted Spotify with recommendation algorithms.
Plausible vs Umami for self-hosted analytics: Plausible is more polished. Umami is more customizable. Both are privacy-respecting and lightweight.
Automated backups that you never test are just false confidence. Quarterly restore drills should be part of every homelab routine.
Atuin: shell history sync across machines. Self-host the server, encrypted sync. Never lose a command. Never wonder 'what was that kubectl command?'
Caddy placeholders: {http.request.host}, {http.request.uri}. Build dynamic reverse proxy configs that handle multiple services with one block.
Most overengineered homelab component? Mine was probably the monitoring stack. Prometheus + Grafana + Loki + Alertmanager for 15 containers.
If a self-hosted app needs more than 10 minutes to deploy from docker-compose.yaml, its documentation needs work.
Radicale: CalDAV/CardDAV in a single Python file. Calendar and contacts sync that uses less RAM than the text editor you're reading this in.
Memos vs Standard Notes for quick notes: Memos for microblog-style capture. Standard Notes for organized, encrypted note-taking. Different use cases.
Docker container debugging shortcut: `docker compose exec service_name sh` (or bash). Get a shell inside any running container instantly.
The Docker Hub rate limit pushed me to self-host a registry mirror. Ended up being one of the best infra decisions I made.
Homepage dashboard supports service widgets. Sonarr, Radarr, Pi-hole, Jellyfin ‚Äî not just links, actual live data from your services.
What's the self-hosted service you tried, didn't like, and went back to the cloud version? No judgment.
Docker Compose is infrastructure as code for normal people. Terraform is for clouds. Compose is for your closet server. Both valid.
Use `docker compose convert` to validate and normalize your compose file. Catches errors and shows the fully resolved output.
Stirling PDF: every PDF operation you'd normally use a sketchy website for. Runs locally, processes locally. Your documents never leave your server.
Synology DSM is user-friendly but locks you into their hardware. TrueNAS on commodity hardware: freedom + ZFS + zero vendor lock-in.
Running your DNS (Pi-hole/AdGuard) is the simplest way to protect your entire network. One config change on the router. Every device benefits.
Docker tip: `docker compose up -d --no-deps service_name` restarts one service without touching its dependencies. Surgical restarts.
LibreSpeed: self-hosted speed test server. Test connectivity to your homelab from anywhere. Also useful for diagnosing internal network issues.
How do you handle service discovery in your homelab? I use Traefik labels. Some people prefer manual Caddy configs. What works for you?
ECC RAM in a homelab is nice insurance but non-ECC hasn't caused me a single issue in 5 years. Spend the savings on better backup storage.
Use `docker compose alpha viz` to generate a visual dependency graph of your services. Useful for understanding complex stacks.
Dockge: Docker Compose management with a nice web UI. Edit compose files, see logs, manage stacks. Lighter than Portainer.
For CI/CD on your homelab: Woodpecker for simplicity, Drone for features, Gitea Actions for GitHub compatibility. All run in Docker.
The 'ideal homelab' doesn't exist. The best homelab is the one that solves YOUR problems. Don't build someone else's setup.

Self-hosting is digital homesteading. Own your infrastructure like you'd own your land. Cloud is renting.
Watchtower with WATCHTOWER_CLEANUP=true removes old images after updating. Keeps your disk clean automatically. #docker
Use `docker compose down && docker compose up -d` instead of `restart`. Fresh container from the image, not a process restart. #docker
Favorite Docker image that just works out of the box? linuxserver.io images are consistently excellent.
LXC containers on Proxmox are underrated. Lower overhead than VMs, better isolation than Docker. Great for single-app servers.
Tailscale MagicDNS: access your homelab services by name from anywhere. No manual DNS entries needed. Just works. #tailscale
Docker logs: `docker compose logs -f --tail=0` shows only NEW log lines. Perfect for watching what happens after a config change.
Google Workspace Starter: $7.20/user/mo. Self-hosted: Nextcloud + Radicale + docker-mailserver = $0/user. Your tools, your rules.
'Docker uses too much disk space.' Set log limits and prune unused images. My 40+ container setup uses 12GB total.
What's your homelab naming scheme? I use service.home.lab for everything. Clean, predictable, easy to remember.
Ansible + Docker Compose is the dream team. Ansible deploys compose files, manages config, handles secrets. Reproducible infra.
Nginx Proxy Manager: if you want a GUI for reverse proxy config. Not the lightest option, but beginner-friendly. #selfhosted
Use Docker's json-file log driver with max-size: 10m and max-file: 3 globally. Prevents runaway logs from any container. #docker
Home Assistant OS vs Docker: HA OS for beginners (add-ons are easy). Docker for people who want to manage everything themselves.
The RSS revival is real. Podcasts, blogs, YouTube ‚Äî all have RSS feeds. Self-host FreshRSS and reclaim your content diet.
Speedtest Tracker: automated speed tests on a schedule with historical graphs. Know if your ISP delivers what you pay for. #selfhosted
'Nobody uses RSS anymore.' Tell that to the millions of podcast listeners. RSS never died ‚Äî it just stopped being trendy.
Is Docker Swarm dead? I still find it simpler than k3s for small multi-node setups. Two commands and you have clustering.
Pin your DNS server's IP as static in your router DHCP settings. Prevents DNS outage if the server gets a new DHCP lease.
Self-hosted wikis beat Notion for documentation. BookStack, Wiki.js, or Outline ‚Äî your knowledge doesn't belong on someone else's server.
ctop: terminal-based Docker container monitor. Like htop but for containers. CPU, RAM, network per container at a glance. #docker
Vercel Pro: $20/month. Caddy on your own server: $0. For personal projects, you don't need a deployment platform.
Use `docker compose pull --quiet` in cron jobs. No output unless there's an error. Clean logs for automated scripts. #docker
The best thing about self-hosting: no account required. No email, no password, no 2FA. Just open the URL and use the service.
Do you run your homelab 24/7 or wake-on-LAN? I run 24/7 because the N100 uses less power than a light bulb.
Telegraf + InfluxDB + Grafana: the TIG stack for time-series monitoring. Alternative to Prometheus + Grafana. Both work great.
'You need a domain name to self-host.' Nope. Local IP + nip.io or local DNS works perfectly for LAN-only services.
SSD vs HDD for home servers: SSD for OS and apps (speed matters). HDD for bulk media storage (cost per TB matters). Use both.
Docker Compose labels for Traefik: `traefik.http.routers.app.rule=Host(\`app.domain.com\`)`. Auto-discovery beats manual config.
Bitwarden's free tier is fine. But Vaultwarden gives you premium features at zero cost. Self-hosting wins again. #selfhosted
Crowdsec scenarios: detect SSH brute force, HTTP scanning, credential stuffing. All from reading your existing logs. Zero added attack surface.
What's the most reliable self-hosted service in your stack? Mine: WireGuard. 500+ days, zero issues, zero intervention.
ChatGPT Plus: $20/month. Ollama + Open WebUI: $0/month + your electricity. No usage caps, full privacy. #selfhosted #ai
Every homelab should have a status page. Uptime Kuma generates one automatically. Share it with family so they stop asking 'is it down?'
Use `docker compose config --no-interpolate` to see your compose file without variable substitution. Debug .env issues. #docker
OliveTin: run predefined shell commands from a web UI. Restart services, run backups, trigger scripts ‚Äî all from your phone. #selfhosted
'Self-hosting is antisocial.' My family group chat on Matrix is self-hosted. My photo sharing with grandparents is on Immich. It's more social.
Favorite monitoring notification channel? Telegram bot, Discord webhook, email, or ntfy? I'm all-in on ntfy now.
Don't run databases in Docker unless you understand volume persistence. Lost data from `docker compose down -v` is a rite of passage.
Self-hosting pro move: test updates on a staging server first. Clone your compose stack to a test VM, update there, verify, then update production.
Docker Compose project names matter. Set them explicitly with COMPOSE_PROJECT_NAME. Avoids confusion when running multiple stacks.
Bookstack's export to PDF feature is legitimately useful. Document everything in your wiki, export as PDF when you need to share with non-tech people.
What's the self-hosted service you've recommended to the most people? I always lead with Pi-hole. Visual proof of how much tracking happens.
The best homelab project is the one that solves an actual problem you have. Not the coolest, not the most technical ‚Äî the most useful.
When Docker containers can't resolve DNS: check if you have DNS set in daemon.json. Docker uses 8.8.8.8 by default if host DNS isn't accessible.
CyberChef: self-hosted data analysis toolkit. Encryption, encoding, compression, hashing ‚Äî all in a browser-based tool. The 'Swiss Army Knife' of data.

Running containers in rootless Docker mode eliminates the biggest security concern. No daemon running as root. Worth the minimal setup effort.
Docker tip: `docker compose exec -T service command` for non-interactive execution. Essential for scripting and cron jobs.
LocalAI: drop-in OpenAI API replacement running on your hardware. Point any ChatGPT-compatible tool at localhost. Zero code changes needed.
What's the self-hosted service that surprised you most? I didn't expect Paperless-ngx to become one of my most-used tools.
Cloud vendor lock-in is real. Every proprietary format, every custom API, every closed ecosystem makes it harder to leave. Self-hosting is the exit plan.
Use `docker compose ps --format json` for machine-readable output. Pipe to jq for scripting around container status.
Forgejo runners: CI/CD that runs right alongside your code. Define pipelines in YAML, execute in Docker containers. GitHub Actions compatible syntax.
For home NAS storage: ZFS for data integrity (checksums + snapshots). Btrfs for flexibility (easier resize). Both beat ext4 for important data.
Immich proving that FOSS can match commercial UX is important for the whole self-hosting movement. It raises the bar for every project.

Paperless-ngx consumption folder: drop PDFs in a folder, they get auto-imported, OCR'd, and tagged. Scanner to searchable archive, fully automated.

Planka: kanban board that actually looks good. Real-time updates, file attachments, due dates. Self-hosted Trello that's genuinely pleasant to use.

Day 1: why won't this DNS work?

Ceph maintenance tip: before doing rolling OSD upgrades, set BOTH `noout` AND `norebalance`. `noout` alone prevents marking OSDs as out, but rebalancing can still trigger from weight changes. Belt and suspenders.

#selfhosted #homelab #ceph #storage #linux #sysadmin

Docker secrets vs .env files:

.env = plaintext on disk, loaded as env vars
Docker secrets = encrypted at rest (swarm), mounted as files in /run/secrets/

For personal homelab: .env is fine.
For anything with real credentials: use secrets.

The self-hosting community on the fediverse is dramatically more engaged than on X or Bluesky. Mastodon posts get 3-5x the engagement rate. Makes sense -- FOSS enthusiasts congregate where the infrastructure matches their values.

Nextcloud + MariaDB performance tip: if browsing image folders causes the DB to spike, it's the file cache recalculating checksums.

Fix: switch to PostgreSQL (handles concurrent writes better) and set `preview_max_x`/`preview_max_y` in config.php to limit preview generation.

#nextcloud #selfhosted #homelab #docker #mariadb #postgresql

Self-hosted email is the boss battle of self-hosting.

Not because the software is hard -- docker-mailserver is straightforward.

It's because Google and Microsoft blacklist entire residential IP ranges and there's no support channel to fix it.

Workaround: relay outbound through a $5/month VPS.

Traefik tip: if you're running Docker Compose and want automatic HTTPS, Traefik with Let's Encrypt is the path of least resistance. Add labels to your containers, point DNS, done. No manual cert management.

HAProxy is faster at raw throughput but Traefik wins on DX for Docker setups.

Hot take: for a single-server homelab, you do NOT need Kubernetes. Docker Compose handles 95% of use cases with 5% of the complexity.

k3s is cool. But if you're running 10-20 services on one box, Compose + a reverse proxy is the right tool.

Scale when you need to, not when you imagine you might.

#selfhosted #homelab #docker #kubernetes #k3s #devops

TCO of self-hosting storage:

4-bay NAS, 4x4TB = ~$500 upfront
Power: ~35W idle = $3-5/month
Drive replacement: ~$80 every 3-5 years

vs. iCloud 2TB = $10/month ($600 over 5 years)

Self-hosting breaks even in ~2 years with 4x the storage.

If you're self-hosting DNS with Pi-hole or AdGuard Home, add Unbound as your recursive resolver. Your DNS queries stay on your network instead of going to Cloudflare/Google upstream. Pi-hole handles blocking, Unbound handles resolution. Clean separation.

Self-hosting email deliverability checklist:

1. SPF record ‚úì
2. DKIM signing ‚úì
3. DMARC policy ‚úì
4. Reverse DNS (PTR) ‚úì
5. Clean IP (not on blocklists) ‚úì
6. SMTP relay via VPS for residential IPs ‚úì

Most people nail 1-4 and skip 5-6. That's where deliverability dies.

#selfhosted #email #homelab #privacy #docker #sysadmin

Traefik vs HAProxy for Docker:

Traefik: auto-discovers containers via labels. Zero manual config for new services. Built for Docker.

HAProxy: manual config but faster throughput, better for high-traffic production.

For homelab: Traefik.
For 10K+ req/sec: HAProxy.

The best thing about self-hosting your password manager (Vaultwarden) isn't privacy -- it's that it uses 50MB of RAM instead of Bitwarden's 2GB+. On a homelab where every MB counts, that difference matters.

OpenVPN 2.7.0's ovpn kernel module (DCO) is a game-changer. Encryption moves to kernel space, closing the performance gap with WireGuard significantly.

Still, WireGuard's simpler config wins for most homelabbers. But if you need TCP fallback for restrictive networks, OpenVPN is back in the conversation.

#selfhosted #vpn #wireguard #openvpn #homelab #linux

OpenVPN 2.7.0 with the ovpn kernel module (DCO) nearly matches WireGuard performance by moving encryption to kernel space.

WireGuard still wins on simplicity. But for TCP fallback on restrictive networks, OpenVPN is worth reconsidering.

#selfhosted #vpn

Hot take update: OpenVPN 2.7.0 with DCO (Data Channel Offload) closes the performance gap with WireGuard by moving encryption to kernel space.

WireGuard is still simpler to set up. But the speed argument is no longer one-sided.

Ceph maintenance tip: Before rebooting a storage node, set BOTH noout AND norebalance flags.

noout: prevents OSDs from being marked down
norebalance: prevents PG redistribution while you're working

Forgetting norebalance means your cluster starts shuffling data the moment an OSD restarts, even with noout set.

`ceph osd set noout && ceph osd set norebalance`

#ceph #selfhosted #homelab #storage #linux

Ceph maintenance tip:

Set BOTH noout AND norebalance before rebooting nodes.

noout alone doesn't prevent PG redistribution ‚Äî your cluster will still shuffle data when OSDs restart.

ceph osd set noout && ceph osd set norebalance

#selfhosted #ceph

Ceph storage tip: before rebooting a node, set both noout AND norebalance flags.

noout alone prevents marking OSDs down, but doesn't stop PG redistribution. You need both to keep your cluster calm during maintenance.

Nextcloud preview generation can kill your database.

Opening a folder with 100+ images triggers on-demand thumbnail creation, flooding MariaDB with concurrent queries.

Fix: Set preview_concurrency=1 in config.php, then use the pre-generate previews app to process thumbnails during off-hours.

Or switch to PostgreSQL ‚Äî it handles the concurrency better.

#nextcloud #selfhosted #homelab #docker #foss

Nextcloud performance tip: preview generation can overwhelm MariaDB when you open image-heavy folders.

Set preview_concurrency=1 in config.php and use the pre-generate previews app to process thumbnails offline.

Or: switch to PostgreSQL.

#selfhosted #nextcloud

Nextcloud slow when browsing photos? The preview generator hits MariaDB hard when creating thumbnails for a whole folder at once.

Fix: preview_concurrency=1 in config.php + pre-generate previews app for background processing. PostgreSQL handles it better too.

NAS buying tip: start with 4 bays and enterprise drives.

Enterprise: 550TB/year workload rating
Desktop: 180TB/year

Desktop drives in a NAS fail faster. The upfront savings get eaten by replacement costs and data recovery.

#selfhosted #homelab #nas

NAS advice: start with 4 bays + enterprise drives. The workload rating difference is huge (550TB/yr vs 180TB/yr for desktop drives).

And factor in the real TCO: 40-60W idle power (5-50/yr), replacement drives, and your time. Self-hosted storage isn't always cheaper.

Ceph cluster suddenly rebalancing after years of stability? Check three things:

1. PG autoscaler defaults changed during your last version upgrade
2. OSD nearfull ratio crossed as data grew
3. BlueStore migration altered crush rules

`ceph config dump | grep autoscal` reveals the culprit most of the time.

#selfhosted #homelab #ceph #storage #linux #sysadmin

Ceph cluster rebalancing out of nowhere?

Check if pg_autoscale_mode flipped to "on" during your last upgrade. Pacific‚ÜíQuincy is notorious for this.

`ceph config dump | grep autoscal` will tell you immediately.

If your Ceph cluster started rebalancing unexpectedly after years of stability, the usual suspect is a version upgrade changing PG autoscaler defaults. Especially Pacific to Quincy.

ceph config dump | grep autoscal reveals whether autoscale mode changed without you noticing.

Nextcloud tip: if your instance locks up when opening a large image folder for the first time, it's the filecache recalculation.

Fix: set `preview_concurrency` to 1-2 in config.php. Also consider `occ preview:pre-generate` on a cron schedule so previews are ready before users hit them.

#selfhosted #nextcloud #homelab #docker #foss

Nextcloud killing your database when opening image folders?

That's the filecache recalculation. MariaDB row locks pile up on oc_filecache.

Fix: preview_concurrency = 1-2 in config.php. Or switch to PostgreSQL ‚Äî handles concurrent writes better.

Nextcloud performance tip: if the instance locks up when opening large image folders, it's recalculating file caches.

Set preview_concurrency to 1-2 in config.php. Better yet, run occ preview:pre-generate on a cron so thumbnails are ready before users access them.

Cilium's Hubble is the single best reason to choose it over Calico or Flannel for Kubernetes networking.

Seeing L7 traffic flows in real time ‚Äî HTTP paths, DNS queries, not just L3/L4 ‚Äî turns network debugging from guesswork into data.

The eBPF dataplane skipping iptables entirely is the bonus, not the main event.

#kubernetes #k8s #selfhosted #homelab #docker #linux #cilium

Cilium's Hubble is the best argument for Cilium over Calico.

eBPF performance is the bonus. Real-time L7 visibility ‚Äî HTTP paths, DNS queries, actual traffic flows ‚Äî is the killer feature.

`hubble observe --pod` during network policy debugging saves hours.

Hot take: Cilium's Hubble dashboard is the real reason to choose it over Calico or Flannel for Kubernetes networking.

The eBPF performance gains are nice, but seeing L7 traffic flows in real time ‚Äî which pods talk to what, which DNS queries go where ‚Äî is what changes how you debug.

OpenVPN isn't dead ‚Äî the 2.7.0 release with the `ovpn` kernel module (DCO) puts it in WireGuard's throughput league.

The caveat: you need to enable DCO explicitly and configure it correctly. WireGuard is still harder to misconfigure.

Pick WireGuard for simplicity. Pick OpenVPN 2.7.0+DCO if you need advanced features like per-client configs.

#selfhosted #vpn #homelab #linux #openvpn #wireguard #foss

OpenVPN 2.7.0 with DCO (Data Channel Offload) puts it back in WireGuard's throughput class.

The ovpn kernel module bypasses userspace entirely. But you have to enable it explicitly ‚Äî default configs are still slow.

WireGuard for simplicity. OpenVPN 2.7.0 for advanced features.

OpenVPN 2.7.0 changed the game with DCO (Data Channel Offload). The ovpn kernel module bypasses userspace, putting throughput on par with WireGuard.

Catch: you need to enable it explicitly. Default OpenVPN configs are still slow. WireGuard remains simpler to get right.

Let's Encrypt dns-persist-01 is a game-changer for self-hosters running internal services.

No more DNS API rate-limit failures at 3 AM. No more HTTP-01 workarounds for wildcard certs on LAN-only domains.

If you're running Traefik or Caddy behind NAT, this solves the cert problem for good.

#selfhosted #homelab #letsencrypt #docker #linux #foss #opensource

Docker tag strategy that actually works:

1. Never use :latest in production
2. Pin to major.minor (e.g. postgres:16.2)
3. Even better: use Linuxserver.io date tags (2026.02.20)
4. Roll forward deliberately, roll back by changing one line

Your future self debugging at 2 AM will thank you.

#selfhosted #docker #homelab #linux #foss #devops

Jellyfin can't transcode on a 2-core server ‚Äî but most clients support direct play, which barely uses any CPU at all.

Before upgrading hardware, check if your client supports direct play. Infuse, mpv, VLC all do. The Jellyfin web player doesn't.

Used Intel QuickSync SFF PCs go for ~$50 if you do need transcoding.

#selfhosted #jellyfin #homelab #mediaserver #docker #linux

CORS vulnerabilities in self-hosted apps are especially dangerous because people assume "it's on my LAN, it's safe."

It's not. A malicious webpage can reach your LAN services through your browser. CORS misconfigs let it read the responses too.

Keep your self-hosted apps updated. Watchtower helps for Docker.

#selfhosted #homelab #security #infosec #docker #foss #opensource

Let's Encrypt dns-persist-01 solves the biggest cert headache for self-hosters:

No more DNS API rate-limit failures at 3 AM.
No more HTTP-01 workarounds for wildcard certs on LAN-only services.

If you're running Traefik or Caddy behind NAT, upgrade now.

Docker tag strategy:

‚Ä¢ Never use :latest in production
‚Ä¢ Pin to major.minor (postgres:16.2)
‚Ä¢ Use date tags when available (2026.02.20)
‚Ä¢ Roll forward deliberately

One-line rollbacks > debugging mystery updates at 2 AM.

"Jellyfin needs a powerful server" ‚Äî not really.

Direct play uses almost zero CPU. Most clients support it: Infuse, mpv, VLC, Kodi.

The web player forces transcoding. That's what kills weak hardware.

Used Intel QuickSync boxes: ~$50 on eBay. Problem solved.

Self-hosted apps behind NAT aren't automatically safe.

A malicious webpage can reach your LAN services through your browser. CORS misconfigs let it read the responses.

Keep everything updated. Use reverse proxy auth. Don't assume the firewall is enough.

If your Nextcloud stops responding after an upgrade, check MariaDB's process list. It's probably running a file cache migration that rehashes every file.

Run occ files:scan --all from CLI before the upgrade hits the web UI. Saves you a lot of downtime.

Docker secrets are more secure than .env files for sensitive config. Instead of environment variables visible in docker inspect, secrets mount as files at /run/secrets/ inside the container.

Most popular self-hosted apps support reading config from files now.

Want a self-hosted Discord replacement that doesn't require Docker? Revolt has a native Windows installer. Matrix/Element is the most mature option if you're comfortable with Docker.

The setup complexity gap between these two is massive though. Revolt wins for beginners.

If your homelab power draw suddenly jumps 15-20W and stays elevated, check for scheduled maintenance: ZFS scrubs, RAID checks, backup jobs.

journalctl --since midnight will usually show the culprit. Sustained disk I/O is the most common cause.

Homelab power usage tip: the jump from 20W idle to 37W is almost always sustained disk I/O.

Common culprits:
‚Ä¢ ZFS scrub (weekly default on many distros)
‚Ä¢ RAID consistency check
‚Ä¢ Backup jobs (Borg, Restic, Duplicati)
‚Ä¢ Docker image layer cleanup

Check: journalctl --since "midnight" | grep -i scrub

Ceph rebalancing after years of stability?

Check `ceph osd pool autoscale-status`. The PG autoscaler got more aggressive in Pacific to Quincy. It may have silently decided your pool PG counts need updating.

Also: set `noout` AND `norebalance` before maintenance reboots. noout alone still allows PG redistribution.

Docker image pinning strategy:

Critical services (Vaultwarden, Nextcloud): pin to exact version (x.y.z). Update manually after testing.

Medium-risk (Jellyfin, Immich): pin to major.minor (x.y). Gets bugfixes automatically.

Low-risk (dashboards, monitoring): `latest` is fine. Breaking changes don't matter much.

Pre-1.0 apps break the rules -- minor versions can contain breaking changes.

NAS recommendation for beginners:

Get a 4-bay NAS with enterprise HDDs. RAID 6 if you can afford it -- you can lose 2 drives without data loss.

But a NAS is NOT a backup. Always have a separate backup elsewhere (another location, cloud, or both). RAID protects against drive failure. Backup protects against everything else.

OpenVPN vs WireGuard in 2026:

WireGuard connects in <1s, uses ~4% CPU at line speed. OpenVPN takes 10-15s handshake, 5-10x higher CPU.

But OpenVPN still has use cases: TCP fallback on hostile networks, wider client compatibility, and ovpn-dco kernel module is closing the performance gap.

Use WireGuard unless you specifically need TCP transport.

WUD (What's Up Docker) > Watchtower for anything with persistent data.

Watchtower auto-pulls and restarts. If the new image has a breaking change, your data is at risk.

WUD notifies you first. You approve the update. Much safer for databases, Nextcloud, Immich ‚Äî anything with volumes.
